text: Bossiaea tasmanica is a low-growing shrub in the pea family (Fabaceae), and is native to Tasmania. ==Description== Bossiaea tasmanica is a prostrate shrub growing to about 0.3 m high. Its branching is dense and the branchlets are spiny. The keel is greenish-yellow sometimes which sometimes has a pinkish tinge. Both the calyx and the pods are hairy. It flowers in November and December. It is closely related to B. obcordata, but differs from it in being more prostrate, in having branchlets which are more wax-encrusted, in having blunter spines, narrower leaves and in having a hairy calyx and hairy pods. ==Distribution== It is the only Bossiaea that is endemic to Tasmania and is found in the east of the island. ==Etymology== The epithet rigida was not able to be used since the name Bossiaea rigida Turcz. had been published. The epithet chosen reflects the fact that this Bossiaea is the only endemic species of Bossiaea in Tasmania. ==Taxonomy== The species was first described as Bossiaea cinerea var. rigida in 1903 by Leonard Rodway. In 2012, Ian Thompson revised the genus, Bossiaea, and raised the taxon to a species, naming it, Bossiaea tasmanica. == References == tasmanica Category:Flora of Tasmania Category:Plants described in 1903 Category:Taxa named by Ian R. Thompson
title: Bossiaea tasmanica
